This [[uniform polyhedron compound]] is a composition of 5 [[truncated tetrahedron|truncated tetrahedra]], formed by truncating each of the tetrahedra in the [[compound of five tetrahedra|compound of 5 tetrahedra]]. A far-enough truncation creates the [[Compound of five octahedra]]. Its convex hull is a nonuniform [[Snub dodecahedron]].

== Cartesian coordinates ==
[[Cartesian coordinates]] for the vertices of this compound are all the cyclic permutations of

: (±1, ±1, ±3)
: (±τ<sup>−1</sup>, ±(−τ<sup>−2</sup>), ±2τ)
: (±τ, ±(−2τ<sup>−1</sup>), ±τ<sup>2</sup>)
: (±τ<sup>2</sup>, ±(−τ<sup>−2</sup>), ±2)
: (±(2τ−1), ±1, ±(2τ−1))

with an even number of minuses in the choices for '±', where τ = (1+{{radic|5}})/2 is the [[golden ratio]] (sometimes written φ).

== References ==
*{{citation|first=John|last=Skilling|title=Uniform Compounds of Uniform Polyhedra|journal=Mathematical Proceedings of the Cambridge Philosophical Society|volume=79|pages=447–457|year=1976|doi=10.1017/S0305004100052440|mr=0397554}}.

pages.text:

This [[uniform polyhedron compound]] is a symmetric arrangement of 4 [[octahedron|octahedra]], considered as triangular [[antiprisms]]. It can be constructed by superimposing four identical octahedra, and then rotating each by 60 degrees about a separate axis (that passes through the centres of two opposite octahedral faces).

== Cartesian coordinates ==
[[Cartesian coordinates]] for the vertices of this compound are all the permutations of

: (±2, ±1, ±2)

==See also==
*[[Compound of three octahedra]]
*[[Compound of five octahedra]]
*[[Compound of ten octahedra]]
*[[Compound of twenty octahedra]]

== References ==
*{{citation|first=John|last=Skilling|title=Uniform Compounds of Uniform Polyhedra|journal=Mathematical Proceedings of the Cambridge Philosophical Society|volume=79|issue=03|pages=447–457|year=1976|doi=10.1017/S0305004100052440|mr=0397554}}.

pages.title: Compound of four octahedra with rotational freedom
pages.text:
{|  class=wikitable align=right width="290"
!bgcolor=#e7dcc3 colspan=2|Compound of four octahedra with rotational freedom
|-
|align=center colspan=2|[[Image:UC10-4 octahedra.png|280px]]

|-

|bgcolor=#e7dcc3|[[Subgroup]] restricting to one constituent||6-fold [[Cyclic symmetries|improper rotation]] (''S''<sub>6</sub>)

This [[uniform polyhedron compound]] is a symmetric arrangement of 4 [[octahedron|octahedra]], considered as triangular [[antiprisms]]. It can be constructed by superimposing four identical octahedra, and then rotating each by an equal angle θ about a separate axis passing through the centres of two opposite octahedral faces, in such a way as to preserve [[Tetrahedral symmetry|pyritohedral]] symmetry.

Superimposing this compound with a second copy, in which the octahedra have been rotated by the same angle θ in the opposite direction, yields the [[compound of eight octahedra with rotational freedom]].

When θ=0, all four octahedra coincide. When θ is 60 degrees, the more symmetric [[compound of four octahedra]] (without rotational freedom) arises. In another notable case (pictured), for a certain intermediate value of θ in which 24 of the triangles form coplanar pairs, the compound assumes the form of the [[compound of five octahedra]] with one of the octahedra removed.

==References==
* {{citation|first=John|last=Skilling|title=Uniform Compounds of Uniform Polyhedra|journal=Mathematical Proceedings of the Cambridge Philosophical Society|volume=79|pages=447–457|year=1976|doi=10.1017/S0305004100052440|mr=0397554|issue=3}}.

[[Category:Polyhedral compounds]]


{{polyhedron-stub}}

pages.text:
{| class=wikitable align="right" width="250" !bgcolor=#e7dcc3 colspan=2|Compound of four triangular prisms |- |align=center colspan=2|[[Image:UC30-4 triangular prisms.png|200px]] |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Type||[[Uniform polyhedron compound|Uniform compound]] |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Index||UC30 |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Polyhedra||4 [[triangular prism]]s |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Faces||8 [[triangle]]s,
12 [[Square (geometry)|squares]] |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Edges||36 |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Vertices||24 |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|[[Symmetry group]]||[[Chirality (mathematics)|chiral]] [[Octahedral symmetry|octahedral]] (''O'') |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|[[Subgroup]] restricting to one constituent||3-fold [[Dihedral symmetry in three dimensions|dihedral]] (''D''3) |} This [[uniform polyhedron compound]] is a [[Chirality (mathematics)|chiral]] symmetric arrangement of 4 [[triangular prism]]s, aligned with the axes of three-fold [[rotational symmetry]] of an [[octahedron]]. == Cartesian coordinates == [[Cartesian coordinates]] for the vertices of this compound are all the [[even permutation]]s of : (±1, ±(1+{{radic|2}}), ±(1−{{radic|2}})) with an even number of minuses in the '±' choices, together with all the odd permutations with an odd number of minuses in the '±' choices. == References == *{{citation|first=John|last=Skilling|title=Uniform Compounds of Uniform Polyhedra|journal=Mathematical Proceedings of the Cambridge Philosophical Society|volume=79|pages=447–457|year=1976|doi=10.1017/S0305004100052440|mr=0397554}}. pages.title: Compound of great icosahedron and great stellated dodecahedron
pages.text:
{| class=wikitable align="right" width="250" !bgcolor=#e7dcc3 colspan=2|Compound of great icosahedron and stellated dodecahedron |- |align=center colspan=2|[[Image:Compound of great icosahedron and stellated dodecahedron.png|200px]] |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Type||[[List of Wenninger polyhedron models#Stellations of icosidodecahedron|stellation]] and [[Polyhedral compound|compound]] |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|[[Coxeter diagram]]||{{CDD|node_1|5-2|node|3|node}} ∪ {{CDD|node|5-2|node|3|node_1}} |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|[[Convex hull]]||[[Dodecahedron]] |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Polyhedra||1 [[great icosahedron]]
1 [[great stellated dodecahedron]] |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Faces||20 [[triangle]]s
12 [[pentagram]]s |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Edges||60 |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Vertices||32 |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|[[Symmetry group]]||[[Icosahedral symmetry|icosahedral]] (''I''''h'') |} There are two different '''compounds of great icosahedron and great stellated dodecahedron''': one is a [[dual compound]] and a [[stellation]] of the [[great icosidodecahedron]], the other is a stellation of the [[icosidodecahedron]]. == Dual compound == It can be seen as a [[polyhedron compound]] of a [[great icosahedron]] and [[great stellated dodecahedron]]. It is one of five compounds constructed from a [[Platonic solid]] or [[Kepler-Poinsot solid]], and its dual. It is a [[stellation]] of the [[great icosidodecahedron]]. It has [[icosahedral symmetry]] ('''I'''''h'') and it has the same [[vertex arrangement]] as a [[great rhombic triacontahedron]]. This can be seen as the three-dimensional equivalent of the compound of two pentagrams ({10/4} "[[decagram (geometry)|decagram]]"); this series continues into the fourth dimension as compounds of star 4-polytopes. {{multiple image | align = left | width = 200 | image1 = Skeleton Gr20, size s.png | caption1 = [[great icosahedron]] | image2 = Skeleton GrSt12, size s.png | caption2 = [[great stellated dodecahedron]] | image3 = Skeleton pair Gr20 and dual, size s, thick.png | caption3 = compound }} {{multiple image | align = left | width = 200 | image1 = Skeleton pair Gr20 and dual, Petrie, stick, size s.png | image2 = Skeleton pair Gr20 and dual, Petrie, stick, size s, 5-fold.png | footer = [[Petrie polygon|Petrie]] [[Decagram (geometry)|decagrams]] of both solids }} {{Clear}} == Stellation of the icosidodecahedron == This [[polyhedron]] is a [[stellation]] of the [[icosidodecahedron]], and given as [[List of Wenninger polyhedron models#Stellations of icosidodecahedron|Wenninger model index 61]]. It has the same vertex arrangement as a [[rhombic triacontahedron]], its convex hull. [[Image:Second compound stellation of icosidecahedron.png|240px]] The stellation facets for construction are: {| class="wikitable" |align=center|[[Image:Second compound stellation of icosidecahedron facets.png|240px]]
Facets from triangle |align=center|[[Image:Second compound stellation of icosidecahedron pentfacets.png|240px]]
Facets from pentagon |} == See also == * [[Compound of two tetrahedra]] * [[Compound of cube and octahedron]] * [[Compound of dodecahedron and icosahedron]] * [[Compound of small stellated dodecahedron and great dodecahedron]] ==References== * {{cite book | first=Magnus | last=Wenninger | authorlink=Magnus Wenninger | title=Polyhedron Models | publisher=Cambridge University Press | year=1974 | isbn=0-521-09859-9 }}, p. 90. * {{cite book | first=Magnus | last=Wenninger | authorlink=Magnus Wenninger | title=Dual Models | publisher=Cambridge University Press | year=1983 | isbn=0-521-54325-8 }}, pp. 51-53. * [[H. Cundy]] and [[A. Rollett]] ''Great Icosahedron Plus Great Stellated Dodecahedron.'' §3.10.4 in Mathematical Models, 3rd ed. Stradbroke, England: Tarquin Pub., pp. 132-133, 1989. == External links == *{{MathWorld |urlname=GreatIcosahedron-GreatStellatedDodecahedronCompound |title=Great Icosahedron-Great Stellated Dodecahedron Compound}} * [http://www.software3d.com/GreatStelDod+GreatIcos.php Great Stellated Dodecahedron plus Great Icosahedron - metallic paper model] * [[VRML]] [http://www.georgehart.com/virtual-polyhedra/vrml/compound_of_great_icosahedron_and_dual.wrl George Hart: VRML transparent model] [[Category:Polyhedral stellation]] [[Category:Polyhedral compounds]] {{polyhedron-stub}}

pages.title: Compound of six cubes with rotational freedom
pages.text:
{|  class=wikitable align=right width="290"
!bgcolor=#e7dcc3 colspan=2|Compound of six cubes with rotational freedom
|-
|align=center colspan=2|[[Image:UC07-6 cubes.png|280px]]
|-
|bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Type||[[Uniform polyhedron compound|Uniform compound]]
|-
|bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Index||UC<sub>7</sub>
|-
|bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Polyhedra||6 [[cube (geometry)|cubes]]
|-
|bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Faces||12+24 [[Square (geometry)|squares]]
|-
|bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Edges||72
|-
|bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Vertices||48
|-
|bgcolor=#e7dcc3|[[Symmetry group]]||[[Octahedral symmetry|octahedral]] (''O''<sub>h</sub>)
|-
|bgcolor=#e7dcc3|[[Subgroup]] restricting to one constituent||4-fold [[Cyclic symmetries|rotational]] (''C''<sub>4h</sub>)
|}
This [[uniform polyhedron compound]] is a symmetric arrangement of 6 [[cube (geometry)|cubes]], considered as [[square prism]]s. It can be constructed by superimposing six identical cubes, and then rotating them in pairs about the three axes that pass through the centres of two opposite cubic faces. Each cube is rotated by an equal (and opposite, within a pair) angle θ.

When θ=0, all six cubes coincide. When θ is 45 degrees, the cubes coincide in pairs yielding (two superimposed copies of) the [[compound of three cubes]].

== Cartesian coordinates ==
[[Cartesian coordinates]] for the vertices of this compound are all the permutations of

: (±(cosθ+sinθ), ±(cosθ−sinθ), ±1)

== References ==
*{{citation|first=John|last=Skilling|title=Uniform Compounds of Uniform Polyhedra|journal=Mathematical Proceedings of the Cambridge Philosophical Society|volume=79|pages=447–457|year=1976|doi=10.1017/S0305004100052440|mr=0397554}}.

pages.text:
{| class=wikitable align="right" width="250" !bgcolor=#e7dcc3 colspan=2|Compound of six decagonal prisms |- |align=center colspan=2|[[Image:UC40-6 decagonal prisms.png|200px]] |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Type||[[Uniform polyhedron compound|Uniform compound]] |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Index||UC40 |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Polyhedra||6 [[decagonal prism]]s |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Faces||12 [[decagon]]s,
60 [[Square (geometry)|squares]] |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Edges||180 |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Vertices||120 |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|[[Symmetry group]]||[[Icosahedral symmetry|icosahedral]] (''I''h) |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|[[Subgroup]] restricting to one constituent||5-fold [[Dihedral symmetry in three dimensions|antiprismatic]] (''D''5d) |} This [[uniform polyhedron compound]] is a symmetric arrangement of 6 [[decagonal prism]]s, aligned with the axes of fivefold rotational symmetry of a [[dodecahedron]]. == Cartesian coordinates == [[Cartesian coordinates]] for the vertices of this compound are all the cyclic permutations of : (±√(τ−1/√5), ±2τ, ±√(τ/√5)) : (±(√(τ−1/√5)−τ2), ±1, ±(√(τ/√5)+τ)) : (±(√(τ−1/√5)−τ), ±τ2, ±(√(τ/√5)+1)) : (±(√(τ−1/√5)+τ), ±τ2, ±(√(τ/√5)−1)) : (±(√(τ−1/√5)+τ2), ±1, ±(√(τ/√5)−τ)) where τ = (1+√5)/2 is the [[golden ratio]] (sometimes written φ). == References == *{{citation|first=John|last=Skilling|title=Uniform Compounds of Uniform Polyhedra|journal=Mathematical Proceedings of the Cambridge Philosophical Society|volume=79|issue=03|pages=447–457|year=1976|doi=10.1017/S0305004100052440|mr=0397554}}. pages.text:
{| class=wikitable align="right" width="250"

|align=center colspan=2|[[Image:UC41-6 decagrammic prisms.png|200px]]

|-
|bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Index||UC<sub>41</sub>

|bgcolor=#e7dcc3|[[Subgroup]] restricting to one constituent||5-fold [[Dihedral symmetry in three dimensions|antiprismatic]] (''D''<sub>5d</sub>)

This [[uniform polyhedron compound]] is a symmetric arrangement of 6 [[decagrammic prism]]s, aligned with the axes of fivefold rotational symmetry of a [[dodecahedron]].

== Cartesian coordinates ==
[[Cartesian coordinates]] for the vertices of this compound are all the cyclic permutations of

: (±√(τ/√5), ±2τ<sup>−1</sup>, ±√(τ<sup>−1</sup>/√5))
: (±(√(τ/√5)+τ<sup>−2</sup>), ±1, ±(√(τ<sup>−1</sup>/√5)−τ<sup>−1</sup>))
: (±(√(τ/√5)−τ<sup>−1</sup>), ±τ<sup>−2</sup>, ±(√(τ<sup>−1</sup>/√5)+1))
: (±(√(τ/√5)+τ<sup>−1</sup>), ±τ<sup>−2</sup>, ±(√(τ<sup>−1</sup>/√5)−1))
: (±(√(τ/√5)−τ<sup>−2</sup>), ±1, ±(√(τ<sup>−1</sup>/√5)+τ<sup>−1</sup>))

where τ = (1+√5)/2 is the [[golden ratio]] (sometimes written φ).

== References ==
*{{citation|first=John|last=Skilling|title=Uniform Compounds of Uniform Polyhedra|journal=Mathematical Proceedings of the Cambridge Philosophical Society|volume=79|issue=03|pages=447–457|year=1976|doi=10.1017/S0305004100052440|mr=0397554}}.

pages.title: Compound of six pentagonal antiprisms
pages.text:
{| border="1" bgcolor="#ffffff" cellpadding="5" align="right" style="margin-left:10px" width="250" !bgcolor=#e7dcc3 colspan=2|Compound of six pentagonal antiprisms |- |align=center colspan=2|[[Image:UC27-6 pentagonal antiprisms.png|200px]] |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Type||[[Uniform polyhedron compound|Uniform compound]] |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Index||UC27 |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Polyhedra||6 [[pentagonal antiprism]]s |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Faces||60 [[triangle]]s,
12 [[pentagon]]s |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Edges||120 |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Vertices||60 |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|[[Symmetry group]]||[[Icosahedral symmetry|icosahedral]] (''I''h) |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|[[Subgroup]] restricting to one constituent||5-fold [[Dihedral symmetry in three dimensions|antiprismatic]] (''D''5d) |} This [[uniform polyhedron compound]] is a symmetric arrangement of 6 [[pentagonal antiprism]]s. It can be constructed by inscribing within an [[icosahedron]] one pentagonal antiprism in each of the six possible ways, and then rotating each by 36 degrees about its axis (that passes through the centres of the two opposite pentagonal faces). It shares its [[vertex arrangement]] with the [[compound of six pentagrammic crossed antiprisms|compound of 6 pentagrammic crossed antiprisms]]. == Cartesian coordinates == [[Cartesian coordinates]] for the vertices of this compound are all the cyclic permutations of : (±(3+4τ), 0, ±(4−3τ)) : (±(2−4τ), ±5τ, ±(1−2τ)) : (±(2+τ), ±5, ±(4+2τ)) where τ = (1+{{radic|5}})/2 is the [[golden ratio]] (sometimes written φ). == References == *{{citation|first=John|last=Skilling|title=Uniform Compounds of Uniform Polyhedra|journal=Mathematical Proceedings of the Cambridge Philosophical Society|volume=79|pages=447–457|year=1976|doi=10.1017/S0305004100052440|mr=0397554}}. [[Category:Polyhedral compounds]] {{polyhedron-stub}}

[[Compound of twelve pentagonal prisms]] |} == References == *{{citation|first=John|last=Skilling|title=Uniform Compounds of Uniform Polyhedra|journal=Mathematical Proceedings of the Cambridge Philosophical Society|volume=79|issue=03|pages=447–457|year=1976|doi=10.1017/S0305004100052440|mr=0397554}}. pages.text:

This [[uniform polyhedron compound]] is a [[Chirality (mathematics)|chiral]] symmetric arrangement of 6 [[pentagrammic antiprism]]s, aligned with the axes of fivefold rotational symmetry of a [[dodecahedron]].

== Cartesian coordinates ==
[[Cartesian coordinates]] for the vertices of this compound are all the cyclic permutations of

: (±(τ+√τ<sup>−1</sup>), ±τ<sup>−1</sup>, ±(−1+√τ))
: (±√τ<sup>−1</sup>, ±2, ±√τ)
: (±(−τ+√τ<sup>−1</sup>), ±τ<sup>−1</sup>, ±(1+√τ))
: (±(−1+√τ<sup>−1</sup>), ±(−τ), ±(τ<sup>−1</sup>+√τ))
: (±(1+√τ<sup>−1</sup>), ±(−τ), ±(−τ<sup>−1</sup>+√τ))

with an even number of minuses in the '±' choices, where τ = (1+√5)/2 is the [[golden ratio]] (sometimes written φ).

== References ==
*{{citation|first=John|last=Skilling|title=Uniform Compounds of Uniform Polyhedra|journal=Mathematical Proceedings of the Cambridge Philosophical Society|volume=79|pages=447–457|year=1976|doi=10.1017/S0305004100052440|mr=0397554|issue=3}}.

pages.title: Compound of six pentagrammic crossed antiprisms
pages.text:
{| border="1" bgcolor="#ffffff" cellpadding="5" align="right" style="margin-left:10px" width="250"
!bgcolor=#e7dcc3 colspan=2|Compound of six pentagrammic crossed antiprisms
|-
|align=center colspan=2|[[Image:UC29-6 pentagrammic crossed antiprisms.png|200px]]
|-
|bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Type||[[Uniform polyhedron compound|Uniform compound]]
|-
|bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Index||UC<sub>29</sub>
|-
|bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Polyhedra||6 [[pentagrammic crossed antiprism]]s
|-
|bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Faces||60 [[triangles]], 12 [[pentagrams]]
|-
|bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Edges||120
|-
|bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Vertices||60
|-
|bgcolor=#e7dcc3|[[Symmetry group]]||[[Icosahedral symmetry|icosahedral]] (''I''<sub>h</sub>)
|-
|bgcolor=#e7dcc3|[[Subgroup]] restricting to one constituent||5-fold [[Dihedral symmetry in three dimensions|antiprismatic]] (''D''<sub>5d</sub>)
|}
This [[uniform polyhedron compound]] is a symmetric arrangement of 6 [[pentagrammic crossed antiprism]]s. It can be constructed by inscribing within a [[great icosahedron]] one pentagrammic crossed antiprism in each of the six possible ways, and then rotating each by 36 degrees about its axis (that passes through the centres of the two opposite pentagrammic faces). It shares its vertices with the [[compound of six pentagonal antiprisms|compound of 6 pentagonal antiprisms]].

== Cartesian coordinates ==
[[Cartesian coordinates]] for the vertices of this compound are all the cyclic permutations of

: (±(3−4τ<sup>−1</sup>), 0, ±(4+3τ<sup>−1</sup>))
: (±(2+4τ<sup>−1</sup>), ±τ<sup>−1</sup>, ±(1+2τ<sup>−1</sup>))
: (±(2−τ<sup>−1</sup>), ±1, ±(4−2τ<sup>−1</sup>))

where τ = (1+{{radic|5}})/2 is the [[golden ratio]] (sometimes written φ).

== References ==
*{{citation|first=John|last=Skilling|title=Uniform Compounds of Uniform Polyhedra|journal=Mathematical Proceedings of the Cambridge Philosophical Society|volume=79|pages=447–457|year=1976|doi=10.1017/S0305004100052440|mr=0397554}}.

This [[uniform polyhedron compound]] is a symmetric arrangement of 6 [[tetrahedron|tetrahedra]]. It can be constructed by inscribing a [[stella octangula]] within each [[cube (geometry)|cube]] in the [[compound of three cubes]], or by [[stellation|stellating]] each octahedron in the [[compound of three octahedra]].

== References ==
*{{citation|first=John|last=Skilling|title=Uniform Compounds of Uniform Polyhedra|journal=Mathematical Proceedings of the Cambridge Philosophical Society|volume=79|pages=447–457|year=1976|doi=10.1017/S0305004100052440|mr=0397554}}.

pages.title: Compound of six tetrahedra with rotational freedom
pages.text:
{| class=wikitable align=right width="290"
!bgcolor=#e7dcc3 colspan=2|Compound of six tetrahedra with rotational freedom
|-
|align=center colspan=2|[[Image:UC01-6 tetrahedra.png|280px]]
|-
|bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Type||[[Uniform polyhedron compound|Uniform compound]]
|-
|bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Index||UC<sub>1</sub>
|-
|bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Polyhedra||6 [[tetrahedron|tetrahedra]]
|-
|bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Faces||24 [[triangles]]
|-
|bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Edges||36
|-
|bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Vertices||24
|-
|bgcolor=#e7dcc3|[[Symmetry group]]||[[Tetrahedral symmetry|tetrahedral]] (''T''<sub>d</sub>)
|-
|bgcolor=#e7dcc3|[[Subgroup]] restricting to one constituent||4-fold [[Cyclic symmetries|improper rotation]] (''S''<sub>4</sub>)
|}
This [[uniform polyhedron compound]] is a symmetric arrangement of 6 [[tetrahedron|tetrahedra]], considered as [[antiprisms]]. It can be constructed by superimposing six tetrahedra within a [[cube]], and then rotating them in pairs about the three axes that pass through the centres of two opposite cubic faces. Each tetrahedron is rotated by an equal (and opposite, within a pair) angle θ. Equivalently, a tetrahedron may be inscribed within each [[cube]] in the [[compound of six cubes with rotational freedom]], in such a way as to preserve [[tetrahedral symmetry]]. 

When θ=0, all six tetrahedra coincide. When θ is 45 degrees, the more symmetric [[compound of six tetrahedra]] (without rotational freedom) arises.

== References ==
*{{citation|first=John|last=Skilling|title=Uniform Compounds of Uniform Polyhedra|journal=Mathematical Proceedings of the Cambridge Philosophical Society|volume=79|issue=03|pages=447–457|year=1976|doi=10.1017/S0305004100052440|mr=0397554}}.

[[Category:Polyhedral compounds]]


{{polyhedron-stub}}

pages.title: Compound of small stellated dodecahedron and great dodecahedron
pages.text:
[[File:Compound of great dodecahedron and small stellated dodecahedron.png|thumb|250px|right|Great dodecahedron shown solid, surrounding stellated dodecahedron only as wireframe]]

The '''compound of small stellated dodecahedron and great dodecahedron''' is a [[polyhedron compound]] where the [[great dodecahedron]] is interior to its [[dual polyhedron|dual]], the [[small stellated dodecahedron]].

This can be seen as the three-dimensional equivalent of the compound of two pentagrams ({10/4} "[[decagram (geometry)|decagram]]"); this series continues into the fourth dimension as compounds of star 4-polytopes.

{{multiple image
 | align = left  | width = 200
 | image1 = Skeleton Gr12, size m.png | caption1 = [[great dodecahedron]]
 | image2 = Skeleton St12, size m.png | caption2 = [[small stellated dodecahedron]]
 | image3 = Skeleton pair Gr12 and dual, size m, thick.png | caption3 = compound
}}

{{multiple image
 | align = left  | width = 200
 | image1 = Skeleton pair Gr12 and dual, Petrie, stick, size m.png
 | image2 = Skeleton pair Gr12 and dual, Petrie, stick, size m, 3-fold.png
 | footer = [[Petrie polygon|Petrie]] [[hexagon]]s of both solids
}}
{{Clear}}

==See also==

*[[Compound of cube and octahedron]]
*[[Compound of dodecahedron and icosahedron]]
*[[Compound of great icosahedron and great stellated dodecahedron]]

|bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Polyhedra||10 [[hexagonal prism]]s

|bgcolor=#e7dcc3|[[Subgroup]] restricting to one constituent||3-fold [[Dihedral symmetry in three dimensions|antiprismatic]] (''D''<sub>3d</sub>)

This [[uniform polyhedron compound]] is a symmetric arrangement of 10 [[hexagonal prism]]s, aligned with the axes of three-fold [[rotational symmetry]] of an [[icosahedron]].

== Cartesian coordinates ==
[[Cartesian coordinates]] for the vertices of this compound are all the cyclic permutations of

: (±{{radic|3}}, ±(τ<sup>−1</sup>−τ{{radic|3}}), ±(τ+τ<sup>−1</sup>{{radic|3}}))
: (±2{{radic|3}}, ±τ<sup>−1</sup>, ±τ)
: (±(1+{{radic|3}}), ±(1−τ{{radic|3}}), ±(1+τ<sup>−1</sup>{{radic|3}}))
: (±(τ−τ<sup>−1</sup>{{radic|3}}), ±{{radic|3}}, ±(τ<sup>−1</sup>+τ{{radic|3}}))
: (±(1−τ<sup>−1</sup>{{radic|3}}), ±(1−{{radic|3}}), ±(1+τ{{radic|3}}))

where τ = (1+{{radic|5}})/2 is the [[golden ratio]] (sometimes written φ).

== References ==
*{{citation|first=John|last=Skilling|title=Uniform Compounds of Uniform Polyhedra|journal=Mathematical Proceedings of the Cambridge Philosophical Society|volume=79|pages=447–457|year=1976|doi=10.1017/S0305004100052440|mr=0397554|issue=3}}.

pages.title: Compound of ten octahedra
pages.text:
{| class=wikitable align="right" width="260"
!bgcolor=#e7dcc3 colspan=2|Compounds of ten octahedra
|-
|align=center colspan=2|[[Image:UC15-10 octahedra.png|120px]][[Image:UC16-10 octahedra.png|120px]]
|-
|bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Type||[[Uniform polyhedron compound|Uniform compound]]
|-
|bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Index||UC<sub>15</sub> and UC<sub>16</sub>
|-
|bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Polyhedra||10 [[octahedron|octahedra]]
|-
|bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Faces||20+60 [[triangles]]
|-
|bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Edges||120
|-
|bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Vertices||60
|-
|bgcolor=#e7dcc3|[[List of spherical symmetry groups|Symmetry group]]||[[Icosahedral symmetry|icosahedral]] (''I''<sub>h</sub>)
|-
|bgcolor=#e7dcc3|[[Subgroup]] restricting to one constituent||3-fold [[Dihedral symmetry in three dimensions|antiprismatic]] (''D''<sub>3d</sub>)
|}
These [[uniform polyhedron compound]]s are symmetric arrangements of 10 [[octahedron|octahedra]], considered as triangular [[antiprisms]], aligned with the axes of three-fold rotational symmetry of an [[icosahedron]]. The two compounds differ in the orientation of their octahedra: each compound may be transformed into the other by rotating each octahedron by 60 degrees.

== Cartesian coordinates ==
[[Cartesian coordinates]] for the vertices of this compound are all the cyclic permutations of

: (0, ±(τ<sup>−1</sup>{{radic|2}} + 2''s''τ), ±(τ{{radic|2}} − 2sτ<sup>−1</sup>))
: (±({{radic|2}} − ''s''τ<sup>2</sup>), ±({{radic|2}} + ''s''(2τ − 1)), ±({{radic|2}} + ''s''τ<sup>−2</sup>))
: (±(τ<sup>−1</sup>{{radic|2}} − ''s''τ), ±(τ{{radic|2}} + ''s''τ<sup>−1</sup>), ±3''s'')

where τ = (1 + {{radic|5}})/2 is the [[golden ratio]] (sometimes written φ) and ''s'' is either +1 or −1. Setting ''s'' = −1 gives UC<sub>15</sub>, while ''s'' = +1 gives UC<sub>16</sub>.

==See also==
*[[Compound of three octahedra]]
*[[Compound of four octahedra]]
*[[Compound of five octahedra]]
*[[Compound of twenty octahedra]]

*{{citation|first=John|last=Skilling|title=Uniform Compounds of Uniform Polyhedra|journal=Mathematical Proceedings of the Cambridge Philosophical Society|volume=79|pages=447–457|year=1976|doi=10.1017/S0305004100052440|mr=0397554}}.

pages.title: Compound of ten tetrahedra
pages.text:
{| class=wikitable align=right width="350" !bgcolor=#e7dcc3 colspan=2|Compound of ten tetrahedra |- |align=center colspan=2|[[File:Compound of ten tetrahedra.png|240px]] |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3 width=50%|Type||[[Regular polyhedral compound|regular compound]] |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Coxeter symbol|| 2{5,3}[10{3,3}]2{3,5}Regular polytopes, p.98 |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Index||UC6, [[List of Wenninger polyhedron models#Stellations of icosahedron|W25]] |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|[[Euler characteristic|Elements]]
(As a compound)||10 [[Tetrahedron|tetrahedra]]:
''F'' = 40, ''E'' = 60, ''V'' = 20 |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|[[Dual polyhedron|Dual compound]]||Self-dual |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|[[Symmetry group]]||[[Icosahedral symmetry|icosahedral]] (''I''h) |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|[[Subgroup]] restricting to one constituent||[[Chirality (mathematics)|chiral]] [[Tetrahedral symmetry|tetrahedral]] (''T'') |} The '''[[polyhedral compound|compound]] of ten [[tetrahedron|tetrahedra]]''' is one of the five regular polyhedral compounds. This polyhedron can be seen as either a [[stellation]] of the [[icosahedron]] or a [[Polyhedral compound|compound]]. This compound was first described by [[Edmund Hess]] in 1876. It can be seen as a [[#As a facetting|faceting]] of a regular dodecahedron. == As a compound == [[File:Spherical compound of ten tetrahedra.png|left|160px|thumb|As a [[spherical tiling]]]] It can also be seen as the [[Polyhedral compound|compound]] of ten [[tetrahedron|tetrahedra]] with [[full icosahedral symmetry]] ('''I'''h). It is one of five regular compounds constructed from identical [[Platonic solid]]s. It shares the same [[vertex arrangement]] as a [[dodecahedron]]. The [[compound of five tetrahedra]] represents two chiral halves of this compound (it can therefore be seen as a "compound of two compounds of five tetrahedra"). It can be made from the [[compound of five cubes]] by replacing each cube with a [[stella octangula]] on the cube's vertices (which results in a "compound of five compounds of two tetrahedra"). It has a density of higher than 1. {{-}} == As a stellation == This [[polyhedron]] is a [[stellation]] of the [[icosahedron]], and given as [[List_of_Wenninger_polyhedron_models#Stellations_of_icosahedron|Wenninger model index 25]]. {| class=wikitable ![[Stellation diagram]]!![[Stellation]] core||[[Convex hull]] |- valign=top align=center |[[File:Compound of ten tetrahedra stellation facets.svg|200px]] |[[File:Icosahedron.png|200px]]
[[Stellations of icosahedron|Icosahedron]] |[[File:Dodecahedron.png|200px]]
[[Dodecahedron]] |} == As a facetting == [[File:Icosiicosahedron-in-dodecahedron.png|thumb|100px|left|Ten tetrahedra in a dodecahedron.]] It is also a [[facetting]] of the [[dodecahedron]], as shown at left. Concave [[pentagram]]s can be seen on the compound where the pentagonal faces of the dodecahedron are positioned. {{-}} == As a simple polyhedron == If it is treated as a simple non-convex polyhedron without self-intersecting surfaces, it has 180 faces (120 triangles and 60 concave quadrilaterals), 122 vertices (60 with degree 3, 30 with degree 4, 12 with degree 5, and 20 with degree 12), and 300 edges, giving an [[Euler characteristic]] of 122-300+180 = +2. == See also == * [[Compound of five tetrahedra]] ==References== {{reflist}} * {{cite book | first=Magnus | last=Wenninger | authorlink=Magnus Wenninger | title=Polyhedron Models | publisher=Cambridge University Press | year=1974 | isbn=0-521-09859-9 }} *{{Cite book | last1=Coxeter | first1=Harold Scott MacDonald | author1-link=Harold Scott MacDonald Coxeter | last2=Du Val | first2=P. | last3=Flather | first3=H. T. | last4=Petrie | first4=J. F. | title=The fifty-nine icosahedra | publisher=Tarquin | edition=3rd | isbn=978-1-899618-32-3 | mr=676126 | year=1999 | postscript=}} (1st Edn University of Toronto (1938)) * [[Harold Scott MacDonald Coxeter|H.S.M. Coxeter]], ''[[Regular Polytopes (book)|Regular Polytopes]]'', (3rd edition, 1973), Dover edition, {{ISBN|0-486-61480-8}}, 3.6 ''The five regular compounds'', pp.47-50, 6.2 ''Stellating the Platonic solids'', pp.96-104 == External links == * {{MathWorld|urlname=Tetrahedron10-Compound|title=Tetrahedron 10-Compound}} * [[VRML]] model: [https://web.archive.org/web/20081119051700/http://www.interocitors.com/polyhedra/UCs/06__10_Tetrahedra.wrl] * [http://demonstrations.wolfram.com/CompoundsOf5And10Tetrahedra/ Compounds of 5 and 10 Tetrahedra] by Sándor Kabai, [[The Wolfram Demonstrations Project]]. * {{KlitzingPolytopes|../incmats/e.htm|3D compound|}} {{Icosahedron stellations}} [[Category:Polyhedral stellation]] [[Category:Polyhedral compounds]] {{polyhedron-stub}}

This [[uniform polyhedron compound]] is a composition of 10 [[truncated tetrahedron|truncated tetrahedra]], formed by truncating each of the tetrahedra in the [[compound of ten tetrahedra|compound of 10 tetrahedra]]. It also results from composing the two enantiomers of the [[compound of five truncated tetrahedra|compound of 5 truncated tetrahedra]].

16 [[tetrahedra]] |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Faces||56:
24 squares
32 triangles |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Edges||56 |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Vertices||24 |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|[[Symmetry group]]||[[Hyperoctahedral symmetry]]
[4,3,3], order 384 |} In 4-dimensional [[geometry]], the '''tesseract 16-cell compound'''{{KlitzingPolytopes|../explain/compound.htm|Compound polytopes}} is a [[polytope compound]] composed of a regular [[tesseract]] and dual regular [[16-cell]]. A ''compound polytope'' is a figure that is composed of several polytopes sharing a common center. The outer vertices of a compound can be connected to form a [[convex polytope]] called the [[convex hull]]. The compound is a [[facetting]] of the convex hull. In 4-polytope compounds constructed as dual pairs, cells and vertices swap positions and faces and edges swap positions. Because of this the number of cells and vertices are equal, as are faces and edges. Mid-edges of the tesseract cross mid-face in the 16-cell, and vice versa. It can be seen as the 4-dimensional analogue of a [[compound of cube and octahedron]]. This is one of four compound polytopes which is obtained through combining a regular convex 4-polytope with its dual; the other three being the [[compound of two 5-cells]], [[compound of two 24-cells]] and [[compound of 120-cell and 600-cell]]. ==Construction== The 24 [[Cartesian coordinate]]s of the vertices of the compound are: : 8: (±2, 0, 0, 0), ( 0, ±2, 0, 0), ( 0, 0, ±2, 0), ( 0, 0, 0, ±2) : 16: ( ±1, ±1, ±1, ±1) These are the first two vertex sets of the [[stellation]]s of a 16-cell.[https://www.jstor.org/stable/2314564 The Stellated Forms of the Sixteen-Cell] B. L. Chilton The American Mathematical Monthly Vol. 74, No. 4 (Apr., 1967), pp. 372–378 == Faceting== The [[convex hull]] is the self-dual regular [[24-cell]], which is also a ''rectified 16-cell''. This makes it a [[faceting]] of the 24-cell. The intersection of the tesseract and 16-cell compound is the uniform [[bitruncated tesseract]]: {{CDD|branch_11|4a3b|nodes}} = {{CDD|branch|4a3b|nodes_10l}} ∩ {{CDD|branch|4a3b|nodes_01l}}. {| class=wikitable |+ Graphs in B4 [[Coxeter plane]] !colspan=2|Elements||Compound||Convex hull||Intersection |- align=center |[[File:4-cube t0.svg|160px]]
Tesseract |[[File:4-cube t3.svg|160px]]
16-cell |[[File:Cubeorthoplex-4 B4.svg|160px]]
Tesseract and 16-cell |[[File:24-cell t0 B4.svg|160px]]
Self dual 24-cell |[[File:4-cube t12.svg|160px]]
Bitruncated tesseract |- !{{CDD|node_1|4|node|3|node|3|node}} !{{CDD|node|4|node|3|node|3|node_1}} !{{CDD|node_1|4|node|3|node|3|node}} ∪ {{CDD|node|4|node|3|node|3|node_1}} !{{CDD|node_1|3|node|4|node|3|node}} = {{CDD|node_f1|3|node|4|node|3|node}} = {{CDD|node|4|node|3|node_f1|3|node}} !{{CDD|node|4|node_1|3|node_1|3|node}} |} == See also == * [[Compound of 5-cube and 5-orthoplex]] == References== {{reflist}} * {{MathWorld|title=Tesseract|urlname=Tesseract}} * {{mathworld|title=16-Cell|urlname=16-Cell}} == External links== *[https://robertlovespi.net/2013/04/18/compound-of-the-tesseract-and-its-dual-the-16-cell Compound of the Tesseract and Its Dual, the 16-Cell] *[https://robertlovespi.net/2013/02/06/rotating-compound-of-the-tesseract-and-its-dual Rotating Compound of the Tesseract and Its Dual] [[Category:Polyhedral compounds]] {{Polychora-stub}}

pages.text:
{|  class=wikitable align=right width="290"

This [[uniform polyhedron compound]] is a symmetric arrangement of 3 [[cube (geometry)|cubes]], considered as [[square prism]]s. It can be constructed by superimposing three identical cubes, and then rotating each by 45 degrees about a separate axis (that passes through the centres of two opposite faces). It is also a [[stellation]] of the [[rhombicuboctahedron]].

This compound appears in the [[lithograph]] print ''[[Waterfall (M. C. Escher)|Waterfall]]'' by [[M.C. Escher]]. Its [[dual polyhedron|dual]], the [[compound of three octahedra]], forms the central image in an earlier Escher [[woodcut]], ''[[Stars (M. C. Escher)|Stars]]''.

== Cartesian coordinates ==
[[Cartesian coordinates]] for the vertices of this compound are all the [[permutation]]s of

: (±{{radic|2}}, 0, ±1)

== References ==
*{{citation|first=John|last=Skilling|title=Uniform Compounds of Uniform Polyhedra|journal=Mathematical Proceedings of the Cambridge Philosophical Society|volume=79|pages=447–457|year=1976|doi=10.1017/S0305004100052440|mr=0397554}}.

pages.title: Compound of three octahedra
pages.text:
{| class=wikitable align="right" width="250" !bgcolor=#e7dcc3 colspan=2|Compound of three octahedra |- |align=center colspan=2|[[File:Compound of three octahedra.svg|240px]] |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Polyhedra||3 [[octahedron|regular octahedra]] |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Faces||24 [[equilateral triangle]]s |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Edges||36 |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Vertices||18 |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|[[List of spherical symmetry groups|Symmetry group]]
(Single color)||[[Octahedral symmetry|''O''h]], order 48 |} In mathematics, the '''compound of three octahedra''' or '''octahedron 3-compound''' is a [[polyhedral compound]] formed from three [[octahedron|regular octahedra]], all sharing a common center but rotated with respect to each other. Although appearing earlier in the mathematical literature, it was rediscovered and popularized by [[M. C. Escher]], who used it in the central image of his 1948 woodcut ''[[Stars (M. C. Escher)|Stars]]''. ==Construction== A regular octahedron can be circumscribed around a cube in such a way that the eight edges of two opposite squares of the cube lie on the eight faces of the octahedron. The three octahedra formed in this way from the three pairs of opposite cube squares form the compound of three octahedra.{{citation|title=Octahedra inscribed in a cube|first1=T.|last1=Bakos|first2=Norman W.|last2=Johnson|journal=The Mathematical Gazette|volume=43|issue=343|year=1959|pages=17–20|jstor=3608867}}. The eight cube vertices are the same as the eight points in the compound where three edges cross each other. Each of the octahedron edges that participates in these triple crossings is divided by the crossing point in the ratio 1:[[square root of 2|{{radic|2}}]]. The remaining octahedron edges cross each other in pairs, within the interior of the compound; their crossings are at their midpoints and form right angles. The compound of three octahedra can also be formed from three copies of a single octahedron by rotating each copy by an angle of π/4 around one of the three [[symmetry axis|symmetry axes]] that pass through two opposite vertices of the starting octahedron.{{citation|title=Some interesting octahedral compounds|first=M. J.|last=Wenninger|authorlink=Magnus Wenninger|journal=The Mathematical Gazette|volume=52|issue=379|year=1968|pages=16–23|jstor=3614454}}. A third construction for the same compound of three octahedra is as the [[dual polyhedron]] of the [[compound of three cubes]], one of the [[uniform polyhedron compound]]s. The six vertices of one of the three octahedra may be given by the coordinates {{nowrap|(0, 0, ±2)}} and {{nowrap|(±{{radic|2}}, ±{{radic|2}}, 0)}}. The other two octahedra have coordinates that may be obtained from these coordinates by exchanging the ''z'' coordinate for the ''x'' or ''y'' coordinate. ==Symmetries== [[File:Three flattened octahedra compound.png|thumb|right|The [[First stellation of rhombic dodecahedron|stellated rhombic dodecahedron]], a compound of three flattened octahedra used in Escher's ''Study for Stars'' and ''[[Waterfall (M. C. Escher)|Waterfall]]''.]] The compound of three octahedra has the same [[symmetry group]] as a single octahedron. It is an [[Isohedral figure|isohedral]] [[deltahedron]], meaning that its faces are equilateral triangles and that it has a symmetry taking every face to every other face. There is one known infinite family of isohedral deltahedra, and 36 more that do not fall into this family; the compound of three octahedra is one of the 36 sporadic examples.{{citation|title=Isohedral deltahedra|first=G. C.|last=Shephard|authorlink=Geoffrey Colin Shephard|journal=Periodica Mathematica Hungarica|volume=39|issue=1–3|pages=83–106|doi=10.1023/A:1004838806529|year=1999}}. However, its symmetry group does not take every vertex to every other vertex, so it is not itself a uniform polyhedron compound. The intersection of the three octahedra is a [[convex polyhedron]] with 14 vertices and 24 faces, a [[tetrakis hexahedron]], formed by attaching a low [[square pyramid]] to each face of the central cube. Thus, the compound can be seen as a [[stellation]] of the tetrakis hexahedron. A different form of the tetrakis hexahedron, formed by using taller pyramids on each face of the cube, is non-convex but has equilateral triangle faces that again lie on the same planes as the faces of the three octahedra; it is another of the known isohedral deltahedra. A third isohedral deltahedron sharing the same face planes, the [[compound of six tetrahedra]], may be formed by [[stellation|stellating]] each face of the compound of three octahedra to form three [[stella octangula|stellae octangulae]]. A fourth isohedral deltahedron with the same face planes, also a stellation of the compound of three octahedra, has the same combinatorial structure as the tetrakis hexahedron but with the cube faces dented inwards into intersecting pyramids rather than attaching the pyramids to the exterior of the cube. The cube around which the three octahedra can be circumscribed has nine planes of [[reflection symmetry]]. Three of these reflection panes pass parallel to the sides of the cube, halfway between two opposite sides; the other six pass diagonally across the cube, through four of its vertices. These nine planes coincide with the nine equatorial planes of the three octahedra. ==History== In the 15th-century manuscript ''Libellus De Quinque Corporibus Regularibus'' by [[Piero della Francesca]], della Francesca already includes a drawing of an octahedron circumscribed around a cube, with eight of the cube edges lying in the octahedron's eight faces. Three octahedra circumscribed in this way around a single cube would form the compound of three octahedra, but della Francesca does not depict the compound.{{citation|url=http://www.georgehart.com/virtual-polyhedra/piero.html|last=Hart|first=George W.|authorlink=George W. Hart|contribution=Piero della Francesca's Polyhedra|title=Virtual Polyhedra|year=1998}}. The next appearance of the compound of three octahedra in the mathematical literature appears to be a 1900 work by [[Max Brückner]], which mentions it and includes a photograph of a model of it.{{citation | last = Coxeter | first = H. S. M. | author-link = Harold Scott MacDonald Coxeter | doi = 10.1007/BF03023010 | issue = 1 | journal = The Mathematical Intelligencer | pages = 59–69 | title = A special book review: M. C. Escher: His life and complete graphic work | volume = 7 | year = 1985}}. The discussion of the compound of three octahedra is on pp. 61–62.{{citation|first=Max|last=Brückner|authorlink= Max Brückner |year=1900|title=Vielecke und Vielflache|location=Leipzig|publisher=Teubner|at=p. 188 and Tafel VIII 12}}. As cited by {{harvtxt|Coxeter|1985}}. Dutch artist [[M. C. Escher]], in his 1948 woodcut ''[[Stars (M. C. Escher)|Stars]]'', used as the central figure of the woodcut a cage in this shape, containing two [[chameleon]]s and floating through space. Escher would not have been familiar with Brückner's work and [[Harold Scott MacDonald Coxeter|H. S. M. Coxeter]] writes that "It is remarkable that Escher, without any knowledge of algebra or analytic geometry, was able to rediscover this highly symmetrical figure." Earlier in 1948, Escher had made a preliminary woodcut with a similar theme, ''Study for Stars'', but instead of using the compound of three regular octahedra in the study he used a different but related shape, a [[stellated rhombic dodecahedron]] (sometimes called Escher's solid), which can be formed as a compound of three flattened octahedra.[http://www.mi.sanu.ac.rs/vismath/zefiro2010sept/_Escher's_solid.htm The compound of three octahedra and a remarkable compound of three square dipyramids, the Escher's solid], Livio Zefiro, University of Genova. This form as a polyhedron is topologically identical to the [[disdyakis dodecahedron]], which can be seen as rhombic dodecahedron with shorter pyramids on the rhombic faces. The dual figure of the octahedral compound, the compound of three cubes, is also shown in a later Escher woodcut, ''[[Waterfall (M. C. Escher)|Waterfall]]'', next to the same stellated rhombic dodecahedron.{{citation|url=http://www.georgehart.com/virtual-polyhedra/escher.html|last=Hart|first=George W.|authorlink=George W. Hart|contribution=The Polyhedra of M.C. Escher|title=Virtual Polyhedra|year=1996}}. The compound of three octahedra re-entered the mathematical literature more properly with the work of {{harvtxt|Bakos|Johnson|1959}}, who observed its existence and provided coordinates for its vertices. It was studied in more detail by {{harvtxt|Wenninger|1968}} and {{harvtxt|Coxeter|1985}}. == Other compounds of three octahedra == With the octahedra seen as [[triangular antiprism]]s, another uniform [[prismatic compound of antiprisms]] exists with D3d symmetry, order 12. Each antiprism is rotated 40 degrees. The top and bottom planes can be seen to contain the compound [[Enneagram_(geometry)#Regular_enneagram|enneagram]], {9/3} or 3{3}. :[[File:Compound three triangular antiprisms.png|160px]] ==See also== *[[Compound of four octahedra]] *[[Compound of five octahedra]] *[[Compound of ten octahedra]] *[[Compound of twenty octahedra]] ==References== {{reflist|colwidth=30em}} ==External links== *{{mathworld|title=Octahedron 3-Compound|urlname=Octahedron3-Compound}} [[Category:Polyhedral compounds]]

pages.title: Compound of three square antiprisms
pages.text:
{| class=wikitable align="right" width="250" !bgcolor=#e7dcc3 colspan=2|Compound of three square antiprisms |- |align=center colspan=2|[[Image:UC42-3 square antiprisms.png|200px]] |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Type||[[Uniform polyhedron compound|Uniform compound]] |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Index||UC42 |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Polyhedra||3 [[square antiprism]]s |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Faces||24 [[triangle]]s,
6 [[Square (geometry)|squares]] |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Edges||48 |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Vertices||24 |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|[[Symmetry group]]||[[Chirality (mathematics)|chiral]] [[Octahedral symmetry|octahedral]] (''O'') |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|[[Subgroup]] restricting to one constituent||4-fold [[Dihedral symmetry in three dimensions|dihedral]] (''D''4) |} This [[uniform polyhedron compound]] is a symmetric arrangement of 3 [[square antiprism]]s, aligned with the three axes of 4-fold rotational symmetry of a [[cube]]. == Cartesian coordinates == [[Cartesian coordinates]] for the vertices of this compound are all the even permutations of : (±√(√2+1), ±√(√2−1), ±1) with an even number of minuses in the '±' choices, together with all the odd permutations with an odd number of minuses in the '±' choices. == References == *{{citation|first=John|last=Skilling|title=Uniform Compounds of Uniform Polyhedra|journal=Mathematical Proceedings of the Cambridge Philosophical Society|volume=79|issue=03|pages=447–457|year=1976|doi=10.1017/S0305004100052440|mr=0397554}}. pages.title: Compound of three tetrahedra
pages.text:
{| class=wikitable align="right" width="300" !bgcolor=#e7dcc3 colspan=2|Compound of 3 digonal antiprisms |- |align=center colspan=2|[[File:Compound of three tetrahedra.png|280px]] |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Type||[[Uniform polyhedron compound|Uniform
compound]] |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Uniform index||[[prismatic compound of antiprisms|UC23]] (n=3, p=2, q=1) |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Polyhedra||3 digonal antiprisms
(tetrahedra) |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Faces||12 [[triangles]] |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Edges||24 |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Vertices||12 |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|[[Symmetry group]]||[[Dihedral symmetry in three dimensions|'''D6d''']], order 12 |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|[[Subgroup]] restricting
to one constituent||[[Dihedral symmetry in three dimensions|'''D2d''']], order 4 |} In [[geometry]], a '''[[Polyhedral compound|compound]] of three [[tetrahedra]]''' can be constructed by three [[tetrahedra]] rotated by 60 degree turns along an axis of the middle of an edge. It has [[dihedral symmetry]], D3d, order 12. It is a uniform [[prismatic compound of antiprisms]], UC23. It is similar to the [[compound of two tetrahedra]] with 90 degree turns. It has the same [[vertex arrangement]] as the convex [[hexagonal antiprism]]. == Related polytopes== A subset of edges of this compound polyhedron can generate a compound [[regular skew polygon]], with 3 skew squares. Each tetrahedron contains one skew square. This regular compound polygon containing the same symmetry as the uniform polyhedral compound. :[[File:Skew tetragons in compound of three digonal antiprisms.png|240px]] == References== *{{citation|first=John|last=Skilling|title=Uniform Compounds of Uniform Polyhedra|journal=Mathematical Proceedings of the Cambridge Philosophical Society|volume=79|pages=447–457|year=1976|doi=10.1017/S0305004100052440|mr=0397554}}. == External links == * {{mathworld | urlname = Tetrahedron3-Compound | title = Compound of three tetrahedra}} [[Category:Polyhedral compounds]] {{Polyhedron-stub}}

pages.title: Compound of twelve pentagonal antiprisms with rotational freedom
pages.text:
{| class=wikitable align="right" width="250"
!bgcolor=#e7dcc3 colspan=2|Compound of twelve pentagonal antiprisms with rotational freedom
|-
|align=center colspan=2|[[Image:UC26-12 pentagonal antiprisms.png|200px]]
|-
|bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Type||[[Uniform polyhedron compound|Uniform compound]]
|-
|bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Index||UC<sub>26</sub>
|-
|bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Polyhedra||12 [[pentagonal antiprism]]s
|-
|bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Faces||120 [[triangles]], 24 [[pentagons]]
|-
|bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Edges||240
|-
|bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Vertices||120
|-
|bgcolor=#e7dcc3|[[Symmetry group]]||[[Icosahedral symmetry|icosahedral]] (''I''<sub>h</sub>)
|-
|bgcolor=#e7dcc3|[[Subgroup]] restricting to one constituent||10-fold [[Cyclic symmetries|improper rotation]] (''S''<sub>10</sub>)
|}
This [[uniform polyhedron compound]] is a symmetric arrangement of 12 [[pentagonal antiprism]]s. It can be constructed by inscribing one pair of pentagonal antiprisms within an [[icosahedron]], in each of the six possible ways, and then rotating each by an equal and opposite angle θ.

When θ is 36 degrees, the antiprisms coincide in pairs to yield (two superimposed copies of) the [[compound of six pentagonal antiprisms]] (without rotational freedom).

This compound shares its vertices with the [[compound of twelve pentagrammic crossed antiprisms with rotational freedom]].

== Cartesian coordinates ==
[[Cartesian coordinates]] for the vertices of this compound are all the cyclic permutations of

: (±(2τ−1−(2τ+4)cosθ), ±2(√(5τ+10))sinθ, ±(τ+2+(4τ−2)cosθ))
: (±(2τ−1−(2τ−1)cosθ−τ(√(5τ+10))sinθ), ±(−5τcosθ+τ<sup>−1</sup>(√(5τ+10))sinθ),
:: ±(τ+2+(3−τ)cosθ+(√(5τ+10))sinθ))
: (±(2τ−1+(1+3τ)cosθ−(√(5τ+10))sinθ), ±(−5cosθ−τ(√(5τ+10))sinθ),
:: ±(τ+2−(τ+2)cosθ+τ<sup>−1</sup>(√(5τ+10))sinθ))
: (±(2τ−1+(1+3τ)cosθ+(√(5τ+10))sinθ), ±(5cosθ−τ(√(5τ+10))sinθ),
:: ±(τ+2−(τ+2)cosθ−τ<sup>−1</sup>(√(5τ+10))sinθ))
: (±(2τ−1−(2τ−1)cosθ+τ(√(5τ+10))sinθ), ±(5τcosθ+τ<sup>−1</sup>(√(5τ+10))sinθ),
:: ±(τ+2+(3−τ)cosθ−(√(5τ+10))sinθ))

where τ = (1+√5)/2 is the [[golden ratio]] (sometimes written φ).

== References ==
*{{citation|first=John|last=Skilling|title=Uniform Compounds of Uniform Polyhedra|journal=Mathematical Proceedings of the Cambridge Philosophical Society|volume=79|pages=447–457|year=1976|doi=10.1017/S0305004100052440|mr=0397554}}.

[[Category:Polyhedral compounds]]


{{polyhedron-stub}}

pages.title: Compound of twelve pentagonal prisms
pages.text:
{| class=wikitable align="right" width="250" !bgcolor=#e7dcc3 colspan=2|Compound of twelve pentagonal prisms |- |align=center colspan=2|[[Image:UC35-12 pentagonal prisms.png|200px]] |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Type||[[Uniform polyhedron compound|Uniform compound]] |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Index||UC35 |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Polyhedra||12 [[pentagonal prism]]s |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Faces||24 [[pentagons]], 60 [[Square (geometry)|squares]] |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Edges||180 |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Vertices||60 |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|[[Symmetry group]]||[[Icosahedral symmetry|icosahedral]] (''I''h) |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|[[Subgroup]] restricting to one constituent||5-fold [[Dihedral symmetry in three dimensions|dihedral]] (''D''5) |} This [[uniform polyhedron compound]] is a symmetric arrangement of 12 [[pentagonal prism]]s, aligned in pairs with the axes of fivefold rotational symmetry of a [[dodecahedron]]. It results from composing the two [[Chirality (mathematics)|enantiomorphs]] of the [[compound of six pentagonal prisms]]. In doing so, the vertices of the two enantiomorphs coincide, with the result that the full compound has two pentagonal prisms incident on each of its vertices. == Related polyhedra == This compound shares its [[vertex arrangement]] with four [[uniform polyhedron|uniform polyhedra]] as follows: {| class="wikitable" width="400" style="vertical-align:top;text-align:center" | [[Image:Uniform great rhombicosidodecahedron.png|100px]]
[[Nonconvex great rhombicosidodecahedron]] | [[Image:Great dodecicosidodecahedron.png|100px]]
[[Great dodecicosidodecahedron]] | [[Image:Great rhombidodecahedron.png|100px]]
[[Great rhombidodecahedron]] |- | [[Image:Great truncated dodecahedron.png|100px]]
[[Truncated great dodecahedron]] | [[Image:UC34-6 pentagonal prisms.png|100px]]
[[Compound of six pentagonal prisms]] | [[Image:UC35-12 pentagonal prisms.png|100px]]
Compound of twelve pentagonal prisms |} == References == *{{citation|first=John|last=Skilling|title=Uniform Compounds of Uniform Polyhedra|journal=Mathematical Proceedings of the Cambridge Philosophical Society|volume=79|issue=03|pages=447–457|year=1976|doi=10.1017/S0305004100052440|mr=0397554}}. pages.text:
{| class=wikitable align="right" width="250"
!bgcolor=#e7dcc3 colspan=2|Compound of twelve pentagrammic crossed antiprisms with rotational freedom

This [[uniform polyhedron compound]] is a symmetric arrangement of 12 [[pentagrammic crossed antiprism]]s. It can be constructed by inscribing one pair of pentagrammic crossed antiprisms within a [[great icosahedron]], in each of the six possible ways, and then rotating each by an equal and opposite angle θ.

When θ is 36 degrees, the antiprisms coincide in pairs to yield (two superimposed copies of) the [[compound of six pentagrammic crossed antiprisms]] (without rotational freedom).

This compound shares its vertices with the [[compound of twelve pentagonal antiprisms with rotational freedom]].

{| class=wikitable align="right" width="250" !bgcolor=#e7dcc3 colspan=2|Compound of twelve pentagrammic prisms |- |align=center colspan=2|[[Image:UC37-12 pentagrammic prisms.png|200px]] |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Type||[[Uniform polyhedron compound|Uniform compound]] |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Index||UC37 |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Polyhedra||12 [[pentagrammic prism]]s |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Faces||24 [[pentagrams]], 60 [[Square (geometry)|squares]] |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Edges||180 |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Vertices||60 |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|[[Symmetry group]]||[[Icosahedral symmetry|icosahedral]] (''I''h) |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|[[Subgroup]] restricting to one constituent||5-fold [[Dihedral symmetry in three dimensions|dihedral]] (''D''5) |} This [[uniform polyhedron compound]] is a symmetric arrangement of 12 [[pentagrammic prism]]s, aligned in pairs with the axes of fivefold rotational symmetry of a [[dodecahedron]]. It results from composing the two [[Chirality (mathematics)|enantiomorphs]] of the [[compound of six pentagrammic prisms]]. In doing so, the vertices of the two enantiomorphs coincide, with the result that the full compound has two pentagrammic prisms incident on each of its vertices. == Related polyhedra == This compound shares its [[vertex arrangement]] with four [[uniform polyhedron|uniform polyhedra]] as follows: {| class="wikitable" width="400" style="vertical-align:top;text-align:center" | [[Image:Small rhombicosidodecahedron.png|100px]]

This [[uniform polyhedron compound]] is a symmetric arrangement of 12 [[tetrahedron|tetrahedra]], considered as [[antiprisms]]. It can be constructed by superimposing six identical copies of the [[stella octangula]], and then rotating them in pairs about the three axes that pass through the centres of two opposite cubic faces. Each [[stella octangula]] is rotated by an equal (and opposite, within a pair) angle θ. Equivalently, a [[stella octangula]] may be inscribed within each [[cube]] in the [[compound of six cubes with rotational freedom]], which has the same vertices as this compound. 

When θ=0, all six [[stella octangula]] coincide. When θ is 45 degrees, the [[stella octangula]] coincide in pairs yielding (two superimposed copies of) the [[compound of six tetrahedra]].

== References ==

pages.title: Compound of twenty octahedra
pages.text:
{| class=wikitable align="right" width="290" !bgcolor=#e7dcc3 colspan=2|Compound of twenty octahedra |- |align=center colspan=2|[[Image:UC14-20 octahedra.png|280px]] |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Type||[[Uniform polyhedron compound|Uniform compound]] |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Index||UC14 |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Polyhedra||20 [[octahedron|octahedra]] |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Faces||40+120 [[triangle]]s |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Edges||240 |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Vertices||60 |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|[[List of spherical symmetry groups|Symmetry group]]||[[Icosahedral symmetry|icosahedral]] (''I''h) |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|[[Subgroup]] restricting to one constituent||6-fold [[Cyclic symmetries|improper rotation]] (''S''6) |} This [[uniform polyhedron compound]] is a symmetric arrangement of 20 [[octahedron|octahedra]] (considered as triangular [[antiprisms]]). It is a special case of the [[compound of twenty octahedra with rotational freedom|compound of 20 octahedra with rotational freedom]], in which pairs of octahedral vertices coincide. == Related polyhedra == This compound shares its [[edge arrangement]] with the [[great dirhombicosidodecahedron]], the [[great disnub dirhombidodecahedron]], and the [[compound of twenty tetrahemihexahedra]]. It may be constructed as the [[exclusive or]] of the two [[enantiomorphs]] of the [[great snub dodecicosidodecahedron]]. {| class="wikitable" width="400" style="vertical-align:top;text-align:center" | [[File:Nonuniform2-rhombicosidodecahedron.png|100px]]

[[Great disnub dirhombidodecahedron]] | [[Image:UC14-20 octahedra.png|100px]]

[[Compound of twenty tetrahemihexahedra]] |} ==See also== *[[Compound of three octahedra]] *[[Compound of four octahedra]] *[[Compound of five octahedra]] *[[Compound of ten octahedra]] == References == *{{citation|first=John|last=Skilling|title=Uniform Compounds of Uniform Polyhedra|journal=Mathematical Proceedings of the Cambridge Philosophical Society|volume=79|pages=447–457|year=1976|doi=10.1017/S0305004100052440|mr=0397554}}. This [[uniform polyhedron compound]] is a symmetric arrangement of 20 [[octahedron|octahedra]], considered as triangular [[antiprisms]]. It can be constructed by superimposing two copies of the [[compounds of ten octahedra|compound of 10 octahedra]] UC<sub>16</sub>, and for each resulting pair of octahedra, rotating each octahedron in the pair by an equal and opposite angle θ.

When θ is zero or 60 degrees, the octahedra coincide in pairs yielding (two superimposed copies of) the [[compounds of ten octahedra]] UC<sub>16</sub> and UC<sub>15</sub> respectively. At a certain intermediate angle, octahedra (from distinct rotational axes) coincide in sets four, yielding the [[compound of five octahedra]]. At another intermediate angle the vertices coincide in pairs, yielding the [[compound of twenty octahedra]] (without rotational freedom).

== Cartesian coordinates ==
[[Cartesian coordinates]] for the vertices of this compound are all the cyclic permutations of

: <math>
\begin{align}
& \scriptstyle \Big( \pm2\sqrt3\sin\theta,\, \pm(\tau^{-1}\sqrt2+2\tau\cos\theta),\, \pm(\tau\sqrt2-2\tau^{-1}\cos\theta) \Big) \\
& \scriptstyle \Big( \pm(\sqrt2 -\tau^2\cos\theta + \tau^{-1}\sqrt3\sin\theta),\, \pm(\sqrt2 + (2\tau-1)\cos\theta + \sqrt3\sin\theta),\, \pm(\sqrt2 + \tau^{-2}\cos\theta - \tau\sqrt3\sin\theta) \Big) \\
& \scriptstyle \Big(\pm(\tau^{-1}\sqrt2-\tau\cos\theta-\tau\sqrt3\sin\theta),\, \pm(\tau\sqrt2 + \tau^{-1}\cos\theta+\tau^{-1}\sqrt3\sin\theta),\, \pm(3\cos\theta-\sqrt3\sin\theta) \Big) \\
& \scriptstyle \Big(\pm(-\tau^{-1}\sqrt2 + \tau\cos\theta - \tau\sqrt 3\sin\theta),\, \pm(\tau\sqrt2 + \tau^{-1}\cos\theta-\tau^{-1}\sqrt3\sin\theta),\, \pm(3\cos\theta+\sqrt3\sin\theta) \Big) \\
& \scriptstyle \Big(\pm(-\sqrt 2 + \tau^2\cos\theta+\tau^{-1}\sqrt 3 \sin\theta), \, \pm(\sqrt 2 + (2\tau-1)\cos\theta - \sqrt 3 \sin\theta), \, \pm(\sqrt 2 + \tau^{-1}\cos\theta + \tau\sqrt 3 \sin\theta) \Big)
\end{align}
</math>

where ''τ'' = (1 + {{radic|5}})/2 is the [[golden ratio]] (sometimes written ''φ'').

pages.title: Compound of twenty tetrahemihexahedra
pages.text:
{| class=wikitable align=right width="290" !bgcolor=#e7dcc3 colspan=2|Compound of twenty tetrahemihexahedra |- |align=center colspan=2|[[Image:UC19-20 tetrahemihexahedron.png|280px]] |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Type||[[Uniform polyhedron compound|Uniform compound]] |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Index||UC19 |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Polyhedra||20 [[tetrahemihexahedron|tetrahemihexahedra]] |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Faces||20+60 [[triangle]]s, 60 [[Square (geometry)|squares]] |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Edges||240 |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Vertices||60 |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|[[Symmetry group]]||[[Chirality (mathematics)|chiral]] [[icosahedral symmetry|icosahedral]] (''I'') |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|[[Subgroup]] restricting to one constituent||[[Cyclic symmetries|3-fold rotational]] (''C''3) |} This [[uniform polyhedron compound]] is a symmetric arrangement of 20 [[tetrahemihexahedron|tetrahemihexahedra]]. It is [[Chirality (mathematics)|chiral]] with [[icosahedral symmetry]] ('''I'''). John Skilling notes, in his enumeration of [[uniform polyhedron compound|uniform compounds of uniform polyhedra]], that this compound of 20 tetrahemihexahedra is unique in that it cannot be obtained by "adding symmetry to a group in which the basic polyhedron is uniform". Each tetrahemihexahedron in this compound is embedded with symmetry group '''C3''', which does not act transitively over the tetrahemihexahedron's six vertices. However, the compound as a whole can achieve uniformity because two tetrahemihexahedra coincide at each vertex. == Related polyhedra == This compound shares its [[edge arrangement]] with the [[great dirhombicosidodecahedron]], the [[great disnub dirhombidodecahedron]], and the [[compound of twenty octahedra|compound of 20 octahedra]]. The edges and 20 of the triangular faces occur in one [[enantiomer]] of the [[great snub dodecicosidodecahedron]], with the other 60 triangular faces occurring in the other enantiomer. {| class="wikitable" width="400" style="vertical-align:top;text-align:center" | [[File:Nonuniform2-rhombicosidodecahedron.png|100px]]
[[Convex hull]]
(Nonuniform [[rhombicosidodecahedron]]) | [[Image:Great snub dodecicosidodecahedron.png|100px]]
[[Great snub dodecicosidodecahedron]] | [[Image:Great dirhombicosidodecahedron.png|100px]]
[[Great dirhombicosidodecahedron]] |- | [[Image:Great disnub dirhombidodecahedron.png|100px]]
[[Great disnub dirhombidodecahedron]] | [[Image:UC14-20 octahedra.png|100px]]
[[Compound of twenty octahedra]] | [[Image:UC19-20 tetrahemihexahedron.png|100px]]
Compound of twenty tetrahemihexahedra |} == See also == * [[Compound of five tetrahemihexahedra]] == References == *{{citation|first=John|last=Skilling|title=Uniform Compounds of Uniform Polyhedra|journal=Mathematical Proceedings of the Cambridge Philosophical Society|volume=79|issue=03|pages=447–457|year=1976|doi=10.1017/S0305004100052440|mr=0397554}}. It results from composing the two [[enantiomorphs]] of the [[compound of ten triangular prisms|compound of 10 triangular prisms]]. In doing so, the vertices of the two enantiomorphs coincide, with the result that the full compound has two triangular prisms incident on each of its vertices. == Related polyhedra == This compound shares its [[vertex arrangement]] with three [[uniform polyhedron|uniform polyhedra]] as follows: {| class="wikitable" width="400" style="vertical-align:top;text-align:center" | [[File:Rhombidodecadodecahedron convex hull.png|100px]]

This [[uniform polyhedron compound]] is a composition of 2 [[great icosahedron|great icosahedra]], in the same arrangement as in the [[Compound of two icosahedra|compound of 2 icosahedra]].

The triangles in this compound decompose into two [[Orbit (group theory)|orbits]] under action of the symmetry group: 16 of the triangles lie in coplanar pairs in [[octahedron|octahedral]] planes, while the other 24 lie in unique planes.

The great icosahedron, as a uniform ''retrosnub tetrahedron'' [[Image:Retrosnub tetrahedron.png|50px]], is similar to these snub-pair compounds: [[compound of two icosahedra]], [[compound of two snub cubes]] and [[compound of two snub dodecahedra]].

pages.title: Compound of two icosahedra
pages.text:
{| class=wikitable align="right" width="300" !bgcolor=#e7dcc3 colspan=2|Compound of two icosahedra |- |align=center colspan=2|[[Image:UC46-2 icosahedra.png|300px]] |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Type||[[Uniform polyhedron compound|Uniform compound]] |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Index||UC46 |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3 width=150|[[Schläfli symbol]]s||β{3,4}
βr{3,3} |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|[[Coxeter diagram]]s||{{CDD|node_h3|3|node_h3|4|node}}
{{CDD|node_h3|3|node_h3|3|node_h3}} |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Polyhedra||2 [[icosahedron|icosahedra]] |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Faces||16+24 [[triangles]] |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Edges||60 |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Vertices||24 |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|[[Symmetry group]]||[[Octahedral symmetry|octahedral]] (''Oh'') |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|[[Subgroup]] restricting to one constituent||[[Tetrahedral symmetry|pyritohedral]] (''Th'') |} This [[uniform polyhedron compound]] is a composition of 2 [[icosahedron|icosahedra]]. It has [[octahedral symmetry]] ''Oh''. As a holosnub, it is represented by [[Schläfli symbol]] β{3,4} and [[Coxeter diagram]] {{CDD|node_h3|3|node_h3|4|node}}. The triangles in this compound decompose into two [[Orbit (group theory)|orbits]] under action of the symmetry group: 16 of the triangles lie in coplanar pairs in [[octahedron|octahedral]] planes, while the other 24 lie in unique planes. It shares the same [[vertex arrangement]] as a [[Uniform polyhedron|nonuniform]] [[truncated octahedron]], having irregular hexagons alternating with long and short edges. {| class="wikitable" width=220 |[[Image:Nonuniform polyhedron-33-t012.png|100px]][[Image:Uniform polyhedron-33-t012.png|100px]]
Nonuniform and [[Uniform polyhedron|uniform]] truncated octahedra. The first shares its vertex arrangement with this compound. |} The icosahedron, as a uniform ''snub tetrahedron''[[Image:Snub tetrahedron.png|25px]], is similar to these snub-pair compounds: [[compound of two snub cubes]] and [[compound of two snub dodecahedra]]. == Cartesian coordinates == [[Cartesian coordinates]] for the vertices of this compound are all the permutations of : (±1, 0, ±τ) where τ = (1+{{radic|5}})/2 is the [[golden ratio]] (sometimes written φ). == Compound of two dodecahedra == The dual compound has two dodecahedra as [[pyritohedron]]s in dual positions: :[[File:Compound pyritohedron and dual.png|240px]] == References == *{{citation|first=John|last=Skilling|title=Uniform Compounds of Uniform Polyhedra|journal=Mathematical Proceedings of the Cambridge Philosophical Society|volume=79|pages=447–457|year=1976|doi=10.1017/S0305004100052440|mr=0397554|issue=3}}. == External links == * [[VRML]] model: [http://www.interocitors.com/polyhedra/UCs/46%20-%202%20Icosahedra.wrl]{{dead link|date=August 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} [[Category:Polyhedral compounds]] {{polyhedron-stub}}

pages.title: Compound of two snub cubes
pages.text:
{| class=wikitable align=right width="290" !bgcolor=#e7dcc3 colspan=2|Compound of two snub cubes |- |align=center colspan=2|[[Image:UC68-2 snub cubes.png|280px]] |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Type||[[Uniform polyhedron compound|Uniform compound]] |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Index||UC68 |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|[[Schläfli symbol]]||βr{4,3} |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|[[Coxeter diagram]]||{{CDD|node_h3|4|node_h3|3|node_h3}} |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Polyhedra||2 [[snub cube]]s |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Faces||16+48 [[triangles]]
12 [[Square (geometry)|squares]] |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Edges||120 |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Vertices||48 |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|[[Symmetry group]]||[[Octahedral symmetry|octahedral]] (''Oh'') |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|[[Subgroup]] restricting to one constituent||[[Chirality (mathematics)|chiral]] [[octahedral symmetry|octahedral]] (''O'') |} This [[uniform polyhedron compound]] is a composition of the 2 [[enantiomers]] of the [[snub cube]]. As a holosnub, it is represented by [[Schläfli symbol]] βr{4,3} and [[Coxeter diagram]] {{CDD|node_h3|4|node_h3|3|node_h3}}. The [[vertex arrangement]] of this compound is shared by a convex nonuniform [[truncated cuboctahedron]], having rectangular faces, alongside irregular [[hexagon]]s and [[octagon]]s, each alternating with two edge lengths. ==Cartesian coordinates== [[Cartesian coordinates]] for the [[vertex (geometry)|vertices]] are all the [[permutation]]s of :(±1, ±''ξ'', ±1/''ξ'') where ''ξ'' is the real solution to :\xi^3+\xi^2+\xi=1, \, which can be written :\xi = \frac{1}{3}\left(\sqrt[3]{17+3\sqrt{33}} - \sqrt[3]{-17+3\sqrt{33}} - 1\right) or approximately 0.543689. ξ is the reciprocal of the [[tribonacci constant]]. Equally, the tribonacci constant, ''t'', just like the [[Snub_cube#Cartesian_coordinates|snub cube]], can compute the coordinates as: :(±1, ±''t'', ±{{sfrac|1|''t''}}) == Truncated cuboctahedron == This compound can be seen as the union of the two chiral alternations of a [[truncated cuboctahedron]]: :[[File:Snubcubes in grCO.svg|480px]] == References == *{{citation|first=John|last=Skilling|title=Uniform Compounds of Uniform Polyhedra|journal=Mathematical Proceedings of the Cambridge Philosophical Society|volume=79|pages=447–457|year=1976|doi=10.1017/S0305004100052440|mr=0397554}}.
