pages.title: Compound of two tetrahedra
pages.text:
[[File:Dual compound 4 max.png|thumb|Pair of two dual tetrahedra]] In [[geometry]], a '''[[Polyhedral compound|compound]] of two [[tetrahedra]]''' is constructed by two overlapping [[tetrahedra]], usually implied as regular tetrahedra. == Stellated octahedron == {{See|stellated octahedron}} There is only one [[uniform polyhedral compound]], the [[stellated octahedron]], which has [[octahedral symmetry]], order 48. It has a regular [[octahedron]] core, and shares the same 8 vertices with the [[cube]]. {| |- style="vertical-align: top;" {{multiple image | align = left | total_width = 460 | image2 = Polyhedron 4a.png |width2=1|height2=1 | image3 = Polyhedron 4b.png |width3=1|height3=1 | footer = A tetrahedron and its [[dual polyhedron|dual]] tetrahedron }} | {{multiple image | align = left | total_width = 460 | image2 = Polyhedron 4-4 blue.png |width2=1|height2=1 | image3 = Polyhedron 4-4 dual blue.png |width3=1|height3=1 | footer = The intersection of both solids is the [[octahedron]], and their [[convex hull]] is the [[cube]]. }} |} {| |- style="vertical-align: top;" {{multiple image | align = left | total_width = 460 | image1 = Polyhedron pair 4-4 from redyellow.png |width1=1|height1=1 | image2 = Polyhedron pair 4-4 from yellow.png |width2=2430|height2=2784 | image3 = Polyhedron pair 4-4 from blue.png |width3=1|height3=1 | footer = [[Orthographic projection]]s from the different symmetry axes }} | {{multiple image | align = left | total_width = 460 | image1 = Polyhedron pair 4-4.png |width1=1|height1=1 | image2 = Polyhedron small rhombi 4-4 dual.png |width2=1|height2=1 | footer = If the edge crossings were vertices, the [[Spherical polyhedron|mapping on a sphere]] would be the same as that of a [[rhombic dodecahedron]]. }} |} {{-}} ==Lower symmetry constructions== There are lower symmetry variations on this compound, based on lower symmetry forms of the tetrahedron. * A facetting of a [[rectangular cuboid]], creating compounds of two tetragonal or two rhombic [[disphenoid]]s, with a [[bipyramid]] or rhombic fusil cores. This is first in a set of uniform [[Prismatic_compound_of_antiprisms#Compounds_of_two_antiprisms|compound of two antiprisms]]. * A facetting of a [[trigonal trapezohedron]] creates a compound of two right [[Pyramid (geometry)|triangular pyramids]] with a [[triangular antiprism]] core. This is first in a set of compounds of two pyramids positioned as [[point reflection]]s of each other. {| class=wikitable width=320 |+ Examples !D4h, [4,2], order 16 !D4, [4], order 8 !D3d, [2+,6], order 12 |- |[[File:Compound_of_two_disphenoids.png|200px]]
Compound of two [[tetragonal disphenoid]]s in square prism
ß{2,4} or {{CDD|node_h3|2x|node_h3|4|node}} |[[File:Digonal disphenoid compound.png|180px]]
Compound of two [[digonal disphenoid]]s |[[File:Compound_of_two_triangular_pyramids.png|160px]]
Compound of two
right triangular pyramids in triangular trapezohedron |} ==Other compounds== If two regular tetrahedra are given the same orientation on the 3-fold axis, a different compound is made, with D3h, [3,2] symmetry, order 12. :[[File:Compound two tetrahedra twisted.png|160px]] Other orientations can be chosen as 2 tetrahedra within the [[compound of five tetrahedra]] and [[compound of ten tetrahedra]]l the latter of which can be seen as a [[hexagram]]mic pyramid: :[[File:Compound_tetrahedra_2_of_5.png|160px]][[File:Compound_of_tetrahedra_2_of_10.png|240px]] == See also == * [[Compound of cube and octahedron]] * [[Compound of dodecahedron and icosahedron]] * [[Compound of small stellated dodecahedron and great dodecahedron]] * [[Compound of great stellated dodecahedron and great icosahedron]] == References== * Cundy, H. and Rollett, A. ''Five Tetrahedra in a Dodecahedron.'' §3.10.8 in Mathematical Models, 3rd ed. Stradbroke, England: Tarquin Pub., pp. 139-141, 1989. == External links == * {{mathworld | urlname = Tetrahedron2-Compound | title = Compound of two tetrahedra}} * [http://www.georgehart.com/virtual-polyhedra/compounds-info.html Compounds of Polyhedra] [[VRML]] model: [http://www.georgehart.com/virtual-polyhedra/vrml/compound_of_tetrahedron_and_dual.wrl] [[Category:Polyhedral compounds]] {{Polyhedron-stub}}

pages.title: Compound of two truncated tetrahedra
pages.text:
{| class=wikitable align="right" width="280" !bgcolor=#e7dcc3 colspan=2|Compound of two truncated tetrahedra |- |align=center colspan=2|[[Image:UC54-2 truncated tetrahedra.png|280px]] |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Type||[[Uniform polyhedron compound|Uniform compound]] |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Index||UC54 |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|[[Schläfli symbol]]||a2{4,3} |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|[[Coxeter diagram]]||{{CDD|nodes_10ru|split2|node_1}} + {{CDD|nodes_01rd|split2|node_1}} = {{CDD|node_h3|4|node|3|node_1}} |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Polyhedra||2 [[truncated tetrahedron|truncated tetrahedra]] |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Faces||8 [[triangles]]
8 [[hexagons]] |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Edges||36 |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Vertices||24 |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|[[Symmetry group]]||[[Octahedral symmetry|octahedral]] (''O''h)
[4,3] |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|[[Subgroup]] restricting
to one constituent||[[Tetrahedral symmetry|tetrahedral]] (''T''d)
[3,3] |} This [[uniform polyhedron compound]] is a composition of two [[truncated tetrahedron|truncated tetrahedra]], formed by [[Truncation (geometry)|truncating]] each of the tetrahedra in the [[stellated octahedron]]. It is related to the [[cantic cube]] construction of the truncated tetrahedron, as {{CDD|node_h1|4|node|3|node_1}}, which is one of the two dual positions represented in this compound. The [[vertex arrangement]] is the same as a convex, but nonuniform [[rhombicuboctahedron]] having 12 rectangular faces. == References == *{{citation|first=John|last=Skilling|title=Uniform Compounds of Uniform Polyhedra|journal=Mathematical Proceedings of the Cambridge Philosophical Society|volume=79|pages=447–457|year=1976|doi=10.1017/S0305004100052440|mr=0397554|issue=3}}. {{polyhedron-stub}} [[Category:Polyhedral compounds]]

pages.title: Prismatic compound of antiprisms
pages.text:
{| class=wikitable align="right" width="300" !bgcolor=#e7dcc3 colspan=2|Compound of ''n'' ''p''/''q''-gonal antiprisms |- |align=center colspan=2|''n''=2 {| |- align=center |[[Image:UC23-k n-m-gonal antiprisms.png|150px]]
5/3-gonal |[[Image:UC25-k n-m-gonal antiprisms.png|150px]]
5/2-gonal |} |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Type||[[Uniform polyhedron compound|Uniform compound]] |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Index|| *''q'' odd: UC23 *''q'' even: UC25 |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Polyhedra||''n'' ''p''/''q''-gonal [[prismatic uniform polyhedron|antiprisms]] |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|[[Schläfli symbol]]s
(n=2)||ß{2,2p/q}
ßr{2,p/q} |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|[[Coxeter diagram]]s
(n=2)||{{CDD|node_h3|2x|node_h3|2x|p|rat|q|node}}
{{CDD|node_h3|2x|node_h3|p|rat|q|node_h3}} |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Faces||2''n'' {''p''/''q''} (unless ''p''/''q''=2), 2''np'' [[triangles]] |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Edges||4''np'' |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Vertices||2''np'' |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|[[Symmetry group]]|| *''nq'' odd: ''np''-fold [[Dihedral symmetry in three dimensions|antiprismatic]] ('''D''np''d''') *''nq'' even: ''np''-fold [[Dihedral symmetry in three dimensions|prismatic]] ('''D''np''h''') |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|[[Subgroup]] restricting to one constituent|| *''q'' odd: ''p''-fold [[Dihedral symmetry in three dimensions|antiprismatic]] ('''D''p''d''') *''q'' even: ''p''-fold [[Dihedral symmetry in three dimensions|prismatic]] ('''D''p''h''') |} In [[geometry]], a '''prismatic compound of antiprism''' is a category of [[uniform polyhedron compound]]. Each member of this infinite family of [[uniform polyhedron compound]]s is a symmetric arrangement of [[prismatic uniform polyhedron|antiprisms]] sharing a common axis of rotational symmetry. == Infinite family == This infinite family can be enumerated as follows: *For each positive integer ''n''≥1 and for each rational number ''p''/''q''>3/2 (expressed with ''p'' and ''q'' [[coprime]]), there occurs the compound of ''n'' ''p''/''q''-gonal antiprisms, with symmetry group: **'''D''np''d''' if ''nq'' is odd **'''D''np''h''' if ''nq'' is even Where ''p''/''q''=2, the component is the [[tetrahedron]] (or dyadic antiprism). In this case, if ''n''=2 then the compound is the [[stella octangula]], with higher symmetry ('''Oh'''). == Compounds of two antiprisms == Compounds of two ''n''-antiprisms share their vertices with a 2''n''-[[prism (geometry)|prism]], and exist as two [[alternation (geometry)|alternated]] set of vertices. [[Cartesian coordinates]] for the vertices of a antiprism with ''n''-gonal bases and isosceles triangles are *\left( \cos\frac{k\pi}{n}, \sin\frac{k\pi}{n}, (-1)^k h \right) *\left( \cos\frac{k\pi}{n}, \sin\frac{k\pi}{n}, (-1)^{k+1} h \right) with ''k'' ranging from 0 to 2''n''−1; if the triangles are equilateral, :2h^2=\cos\frac{\pi}{n}-\cos\frac{2\pi}{n}. {| class=wikitable |+ Compounds of 2 antiprisms !{{CDD|node_h3|2x|node_h3|4|node}}
{{CDD|node_h3|2x|node_h3|2x|node_h3}} !{{CDD|node_h3|2x|node_h3|6|node}}
{{CDD|node_h3|2x|node_h3|3|node_h3}} !{{CDD|node_h3|2x|node_h3|8|node}}
{{CDD|node_h3|2x|node_h3|4|node_h3}} !{{CDD|node_h3|2x|node_h3|12|node}}
{{CDD|node_h3|2x|node_h3|6|node_h3}} !{{CDD|node_h3|2x|node_h3|10|rat|3x|node}}
{{CDD|node_h3|2x|node_h3|5|rat|3x|node_h3}} |- |[[File:Compound of two tetrahedra.png|100px]] |[[File:Compound_two_triangle_prisms.png|100px]] |[[File:Compound_two_square_antiprisms.png|100px]] |[[File:Compound_two_hexagonal_antiprisms.png|100px]] |[[File:Compound_two_pentagram_crossed_antiprism.png|100px]] |- align=center valign=top |2 [[tetrahedron|digonal
antiprisms]]
(tetrahedra) |2 [[octahedron|triangular
antiprisms]]
(octahedra) |2 [[square antiprism|square
antiprisms]] |2 [[hexagonal antiprism|hexagonal
antiprisms]] |2 [[Pentagrammic crossed-antiprism|pentagrammic
crossed
antiprism]] |} === Compound of two trapezohedra (duals) === The duals of the prismatic compound of antiprisms are compounds of [[trapezohedra]]: {| class=wikitable |- align=center |[[File:Compound_two_cubes.png|160px]]
Two cubes
(trigonal trapezohedra) |} == Compound of three antiprisms== For compounds of three digonal antiprisms, they are rotated 60 degrees, while three triangular antiprisms are rotated 40 degrees. {| class=wikitable |[[File:Compound_three_digonal_antiprisms.png|160px]] |[[File:Compound_three_triangular_antiprisms.png|160px]] |- ![[Compound of three tetrahedra|Three tetrahedra]] !Three octahedra |} == References == *{{citation|first=John|last=Skilling|title=Uniform Compounds of Uniform Polyhedra|journal=Mathematical Proceedings of the Cambridge Philosophical Society|volume=79|pages=447–457|year=1976|doi=10.1017/S0305004100052440|mr=0397554|issue=3}}.
